I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2003 Country Strategy and Programming Update Mission, the Government of 
Indonesia agreed to include the Urban Air Quality Improvement Sector Development Program 
(the Program) in the 2005 pipeline of projects for Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance. 
ADB intermittently fielded a Fact-Finding Mission (the Mission) from 16 March to 11 May 2004, 
for the technical assistance (TA) to prepare the Program. The Mission and Government reached 
an  understanding  on  the  TA  objectives,  scope,  cost,  consultants’  terms  of  reference, 
implementation arrangements, and schedule.1 A preliminary project logical framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Rapid urbanization and weak enforcement  mechanisms and strategies in Indonesia 
have made air pollution a significant urban health threat, more so for the poor, and resulted in 
loss of productivity for the nation. The United Nations Environmental Program ranks Jakarta as 
the world’s third most polluted megacity, after Mexico and Bangkok. Levels of lead, nitrogen 
dioxide, and particulates in the air are significantly higher than World Health Organization 
standards. Vehicle fleet and industry are two major air pollution sources. Air pollution costs the 
economy at least $400 million every year, which could increase 10-fold by 2010 in the absence 
of pollution control. 
 
3.  ADB has been providing TA and financing support to its developing member countries to 
prepare  policies  and  strategies  to  improve  urban  air  quality.2  Lessons  learned  show  that 
improvement of urban air quality requires multisectoral commitment to formulating and enforcing 
multisectoral policies and regulatory frameworks; adopting regulations and standards in stages; 
and strengthening enforcement capacity and facilities, including those of sectoral agencies and 
local governments.  
 
4.  Parliament has enacted laws on air quality management, including Act 14 of 1992 on 
traffic and land transportation, Act 23 of 1997 on environmental management, and Act 22 of 
2001 on oil and gas. The Ministry of Environment (MOE) has issued regulations, including 
ministerial decrees 35/1993 on Emission Standard for Motor Vehicles, 15/1996 on Blue Sky 
Program, and 45/1997 on Air Pollutants Structured Index. The Ministry of Communications has 
also released ministerial decrees 6 and 7 of 1997 on an environmental management plan and 
an environmental monitoring plan for the transportation sector. Other programs, decrees, and 
standards are associated with air quality management, directed at controlling emissions from 
vehicles and stationary sources. The principal ministries involved in air quality management are 
environment, communications, and energy and mineral resources. The governor of Jakarta has 
also issued relevant decrees.

5.  The Government launched the Blue Sky Program in 1996, which includes controlling 
activities for stationary and mobile sources. For stationary sources, the earlier phase of the 
program focused on plants producing cement, iron and steel, pulp and paper, and coal-fired 
power,  and  targeted  five  of  the  largest  cities:  Bandung,  Jakarta,  Medan,  Semarang,  and 
Surabaya. Due to weak enforcement and coordination among agencies and lack of funding and 
a monitoring mechanism, implementation of the Blue Sky Program has been slow. Supply of 
clean fuel such as unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, and natural gas has been delayed or 
failed. Air monitoring has not been consistent or scientific enough to produce an authoritative air 
quality database for strategic planning. 
 
6.  The challenges to enforcement increased after decentralization in 2001. Act 22 of 1999, 
which came into effect on 1 January 2001, gives regional governments increased powers to 
regulate and manage their functions. The lack of a comprehensive implementation framework, 
coupled  with  regional  governments’  limited  capacity  to  manage  air  quality,  weakens 
enforcement of air quality regulations and harms the health and welfare of urban residents.  
 
7.  An ADB TA3 helped MOE develop a draft policy paper on reducing vehicle emissions, 
which is expected to be endorsed by the minister and other concerned ministers in 2004. The 
paper identified six major categories of actions to be adopted by ministries and agencies to 
improve vehicle emissions: (i) air quality monitoring, (ii) air quality management governance, (iii) 
fuel quality improvement, (iv) vehicle standards and vehicle technology, (v) inspection and 
maintenance,  and  (vi)  transport  planning  and  traffic  management.  A  number  of  policy 
instruments are recommended for each category. Priority activities requiring future funding are 
also recommended. Actions for industrial air pollution control have yet to be identified and 
integrated. ADB is also providing a regional assistance through Clean Air Initiatives–Asia to help 
selected developing member countries, including Indonesia, develop a regional network to 
exchange knowledge and share information on air quality management. Through the regional 
assistance, Indonesia participated in the Forum of Development of Fuel Strategy. 
 
8.  Other international agencies have granted Indonesia TA, including the World Bank 
Urban  Air  Quality  Management  Strategy    (URBAIR)  Jakarta  Program,  Japan  International 
Cooperation Agency Study on the Integrated Air Quality Management for Jakarta Metropolitan 
Area,  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID)  Environmental  Impact 
Management Agency (BAPEDAL) and East Java Pollution Control Implementation Project, and 
Swisscontact vehicle inspection and maintenance. The Government has not fully taken up these 
activities’ recommendations due to the implementing agencies’ weaknesses in policy integration 
and enforcement, and shortage of consistent funding and a strong coordination and monitoring 
mechanism. Therefore, a sector development program is needed to provide financing source 
and technical assistance to strengthen both the central and regional governments’ capacity of 
policy development and their enforcement infrastructure. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The TA’s purpose is to help prepare the Program to strengthen enforcement strategies 
and the framework of urban air quality management in Indonesia. The main focus area could be  
the Capital City of  Jakarta (DKI Jakarta) and its neighboring regencies, or other cities that have 
serious  industrial  or  vehicular  air  pollution  problems.  The  TA  will  review  the  policy  and 
                                                 
3  ADB. 2002. Clean Vehicle Fuel for Blue Skies, Part B. Manila.

3   
regulatory framework, strengthen institutional capacity, develop implementation strategies, and 
prepare an investment plan to improve infrastructure required for air quality management in the 
program area. The initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will be implemented in two phases in 12 months. Phase 1 will be implemented in 
5 months to prepare an air quality management strategy and action plan (SAP), which will 
include policy and investment actions on reducing vehicle and industrial air emissions, as the 
Program’s implementation basis. Phase 2 will be implemented in 7 months to prepare the 
Program  based  on  the  SAP.  Five  cities  (Bandung,  Jakarta,  Jogyakarta,  Semarang,  and 
Surabaya) have been tentatively selected to be consulted during the inception stage. One or 
two will be selected to participate in the Program. 
 
11.  To prepare the SAP, the TA consultants will review the implementation framework and 
effectiveness of the Government’s and donors’ air quality management polices and programs. 
The review will draw on findings and conclusions of previous reviews and reports, including the 
policy paper prepared under the ADB TA on Clean Vehicle Fuel for Blue Skies and the outputs 
of  the  ADB  regional  TA  on  Clean  Air  Initiatives—Asia4, which will then be discussed and 
followed up with the Government through policy dialogue. A time-bound policy enforcement 
framework,  including  activities  to  be  undertaken  by  each  implementing  agency,  resource 
requirements, performance indicators, and a coordination and monitoring mechanism will be 
recommended to strengthen urban air quality management. The SAP will also identify areas 
where the private sector can help improve air quality, or private pro-environmental funds can be 
mobilized for the Program. Monthly technical meetings will be held in phase 1 for stakeholders 
to discuss the SAP’s preparation. A consultation conference will be held to discuss the draft 
SAP. The Government will review the draft SAP during the fifth month of phase 1. 
 
12.  Due  to  the  multisectoral  nature  of  air  quality  management,  holistic  planning  and 
coordination capacity, which the Government lacks, is vital to the Program’s success. A study 
tour in countries where air quality management is successful or in progress will be conducted 
during phase 1 to strengthen the Government’s comprehensive planning capacity. Eight senior 
officials  of  National  Development  Planning  Agency  (BAPPENAS),  MOE,  Ministry  of 
Communication, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, and two city governments will 
attend the study tour, which is tentatively planned to include Republic of Korea; Philippines; 
and/or Taipei,China. The participants will learn air quality management strategic planning and 
enforcement skills. 
 
13.  In phase 2, a feasibility study will be conducted to prepare an investment plan for air 
quality improvement. The plan will cover all aspects related to new investments, including 
technology selection; technical specifications; economic and financial analyses; environment, 
poverty, and social impact assessments; and institutional strengthening to improve air quality 
management. The investments may include, but not be limited to, adding new or rehabilitating 
air quality monitoring and survey equipment, and supporting capacity building and institutional 
strengthening. The plan may also include a mechanism through financial intermediaries to 
provide funds to the private sector to improve air quality. The funds could be used to procure air 
emission  reduction  equipment,  air  quality  monitoring  devices,  a  motor  vehicle  emission 
inspection and maintenance system, natural-gas filling stations and vehicles, and cleaner-
production and energy-efficient technology to meet emission standards. Technical meetings will 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2001. Regional Technical Assistance on Clean Air Initiatives Asia. Manila.

4   
also  be  held  in  phase  2  to  discuss  with  concerned  agencies  the  investment  design  and 
implementation framework. 
 
14.  An international consulting firm associated with a local firm will be engaged to help line 
ministries and selected cities jointly commit to improving urban air quality. The consultants will 
discuss with the public and private sectors to identify potential investment needs and design 
appropriate investment components in line with SAP activities. To facilitate project preparation, 
the consultants will examine in phase 2 the new procedure specified in Ministry of Finance 
Decree  35/2002  to  help  the  central  and  selected  city  governments  comply  with  financing 
requirements. The consultants will also design and conduct a policy development training 
workshop in phase 1, and an air quality management technical training workshop in phase 2 to 
strengthen agencies’ planning and enforcement capacity. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $880,000 equivalent, comprising $390,000 in 
foreign exchange costs and $490,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will provide 
$700,000 equivalent to finance the entire foreign exchange costs and $310,000 equivalent of 
the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, 
funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance in kind the remaining 
$180,000 equivalent of the local currency costs. The cost estimates and financing plan are 
presented in Appendix 3. The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  BAPPENAS,  through  its  Directorate  for  Environment  and  Natural  Resource 
Management, will be the Executing Agency. The ministries of environment, energy and mineral 
resources, and communications; other concerned ministries; and selected city governments will 
be the implementing agencies. A steering committee chaired by BAPPENAS will be set up to 
coordinate  the  implementing  agencies’  views  and  advise  the  consultants  during  TA 
implementation. The private sector, civil society, and NGOs representatives will be invited to the 
steering committee for extensive stakeholder consultation. 
 
17.  The TA will be carried out in two phases in 12 months, from November 2004 to October 
2005. An international consulting firm associated with a domestic consulting firm will undertake 
the TA activities. The international and domestic consultants will be recruited in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Simplified technical proposals will be requested 
and evaluated using the quality- and cost-based selection method to select a consulting firm. 
 
18.  The total consulting services will include 17 person-months of international and 52 
person-months of domestic consultants. Phase 1 will require 6 person-months of international 
and 25 person-months of domestic consultants. Phase 2 will require 11 person-months of 
international and 27 person-months of domestic consultants. Expertise required includes air 
quality management policy and institution development, air quality monitoring, industrial air 
pollution  control,  environmental  economics,  vehicle  inspection  and  maintenance,  transport 
planning, fuel quality, social development, information technology and public awareness, public 
health,  and  government  finance  and  procurement.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  of  the 
consultants are in Appendix 4.

5   
19.  The consultant team should have a home-base office in Jakarta to effectively and 
efficiently  communicate  and  work  closely  with  BAPPENAS  and  implementing  agencies. 
Equipment required for TA implementation will be procured by the consultant in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and retained by BAPPENAS upon TA completion. 
 
20.  The consultants will submit  (i) an inception report at the end of the first month, (ii) 
monthly progress reports at the end of months during which no other reports are due, (iii) a first 
interim report, including the draft SAP, in the second week of the fourth month, (iv) a second 
interim report and a final SAP at the end of the sixth month, (v) a draft final report at the end of 
tenth  month,  and  (vi)  a  final  report  within  3  weeks  after  the  final  tripartite  meeting.  The 
consultants  will  submit  hard  and  electronic  copies  of  all  the  reports  to  the  BAPPENAS, 
implementing agencies, and ADB. Tripartite meetings involving the BAPPENAS, implementing 
agencies, consultants, and ADB, will be held after submission of the inception, interim, and draft 
final reports.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Indonesia  for  preparing  the  Urban  Air  Quality  Improvement  Sector 
Development Program and hereby reports this action to the Board.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
The poverty reduction partnership agreement signed in April 2001 states that, in the medium term, poverty reduction 
development priorities will focus on three major areas of intervention: growth, human resource development, and good 
governance. The urban air quality program in Indonesia contributes directly to environmentally sustainable economic 
growth. Strengthening air quality management framework and enforcement capacity will mitigate air pollution, improve 
living and working environments, and reduce health hazards to the public, including the poor. The Program will also 
promote private sector development in vehicle maintenance and air pollution control sectors, which will then create 
jobs.  
 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Poverty Classification 
   
What type of poverty analysis is needed?   
The urban poor will be among the beneficiaries of improved air quality. The    Non-Poverty 
impacts  will  be  reduced  respiratory  diseases,  less  demand  on  health 
services, and longer earning periods. Secondary data on the poor in the 
selected  cities  will  be  collected,  and  potential  improvement  of  health 
conditions and job opportunities of the poor will be estimated. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?   Yes   No  
The project design will include consultation with the Government; research institutes; the private sector; civil society; 
and potentially affected groups such as factory owners, vehicle owners, bus and taxi operators, and passengers. The 
consultation will include identifying factors that influence the private sector’s decision to improve air emissions, 
incentives to encourage industry and transport sectors to comply with air emission standards, capacity building for air 
quality management, public awareness of health hazards of poor air quality, and opportunities for informal 
employment that could directly benefit the poor. 
 
 
Is there a participation strategy?   Yes    No 
Consultation meetings and workshops will be held to collect stakeholders’ inputs and feedbacks. Data collected will be 
incorporated into the project design. Workshops will disseminate the project design and expected achievements.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  consultant  will  provide  the  following  outputs  to  design  the  Urban  Air  Quality 
Improvement Sector Development Program for Indonesia: 
 
(i)  a strategy and action plan (SAP), which will be basis of the Program’s policy 
component, on urban air quality management for mobile and stationary sources, 
an implementation framework, and an implementation time frame;  
(ii)  an investment plan, including bidding documents and contract packages for the 
public sector to improve air quality management;  
(iii)  an air pollution control facility, which will channel program funds to the private 
sector to reduce air emissions;  
(iv)  workshops and technical meetings to discuss with stakeholders the elements of 
the policy framework, enhance stakeholders’ knowledge of and skills in air quality 
management planning and policy development and air pollution control; 
(v)  a study tour design and arrangement for eight participants from the National 
Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS)and implementing agencies to visit 
one  or  two  countries  in  the  Asia-Pacific  region  to  learn  about  air  quality 
management;  
(vi)  a program implementation framework agreed on by relevant agencies, with a 
specific time-bound and monitorable set of outputs and activities; and 
(vii)  a feasibility study of the Program, including all analyses. 
 
2.  The consulting services will be carried out in two phases in 12 months. An international 
consulting firm teaming up with a domestic firm will be selected to provide consulting services. 
The consultants will work as a team to carry out various tasks to prepare the required outputs, 
under the supervision and coordination of the consultant team leader and deputy team leader. 
The international consulting firm will provide an air quality management and policy specialist for 
a minimum of 7 person-months as the team leader, and experts on air quality monitoring, 
vehicle inspection and maintenance, environmental economics, and environmental and social 
assessment.  The  domestic  firm  will  provide  an  environmental regulation and institutional 
strengthening specialist for 12 person-months as the deputy team leader; and experts on 
industrial  pollution  control,  public  health,  air  quality  monitoring,  transport  planning  and 
management, vehicle maintenance and inspection, fuel quality, public health, public awareness, 
social development, and government finance and procurement.  
 
3.  An estimated 17 person-months of international and 52 person-months of domestic 
consultants will be needed. Phase 1 will require approximately 6 and 25 person-months of 
international and domestic consultants, respectively. Phase 2 will require approximately 11 and 
27 person-months of international and domestic consultants, respectively. The consulting firm is 
encouraged to suggest the best composition and number of experts and arrangement of the 
consultants’ program to deliver the outputs. The following tasks are indicative, which should not 
limit the consultant to undertake any other tasks that are necessary for preparing the required 
outputs. 
 
A.  Phase 1. Preparation of the Strategy and Action Plan 
 
4.  To prepare the SAP on air quality management, the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Review the implementation status and identify strengths and weaknesses of 
policy development work and technical assistance undertaken by Government 
agencies  and  international  funding  agencies,  especially  the  policy  paper  on

(iii)  Discuss  with  the  concerned  central  Government  agencies  and  selected  city

implementing agencies of the Program. 
(iv)  Identify policy and strategy elements to be implemented by each concerned 
Government agency in 5 years. 
(v)  With the Government and private sector, identify areas where the private sector

(vi)  Prepare the SAP based on the above findings, which will include short- (3 years)

(vii)  Conduct monthly technical meetings to discuss the SAP preparation, and a

B.  Phase 2. Feasibility Study 
 
1.  Preparation of an Investment Plan for the Public Sector 
5.  Subject  to  the  implementing  agencies’  confirmation  in  phase  1,  the  investment 
components as suggested in these terms of reference might be revised before phase 2. The 
basic tasks for the phase-2 feasibility study will remain the same. To prepare an investment plan 
for the public sector to enhance air quality management, the consultant will do the following:   
 
(i)  Discuss with BAPPENAS and implementing agencies as confirmed under task 
para. 4 (iii), their air quality management programs, and confirm the program 
area and short-term (3 years) investment need for air quality improvement. 
(ii)  Develop  investment  components  for  each  implementing  agency,  which  may 
include but not be limited to, rehabilitation of the current air quality monitoring 
and data management system; purchase of additional air quality monitoring 
equipment  and  stationary  source  emission  testing  equipment,  and  training 
facilities; retrofitting of the public transport fleet; and recruiting of consulting 
services for the supervision of program implementation. 
(iii)  Review the fiscal system at the central and regional government levels, and the 
annual budget allocation of BAPPENAS and each implementing agency, identify 
sources  of  counterpart  funding,  examine  the  fiscal  capacity  of  selected  city 
governments, clarify the Kepman 351 requirements, and facilitate discussions 
between the Ministry of Finance and implementing agencies at the central and 
city government levels to reach agreements on the on-lending arrangement for 
the investment plan. 
                                                 
1  Ministry of Finance Decree No. 35/2002, which governs the procedure, conditions, and administration of foreign 
loans on-lending to local governments.

Appendix 4  13   
(iv)  Prepare detailed cost estimates for the investment plan and present the cost 
estimates in ADB format using the COSTAB or an equivalent model, and design 
a financing plan for the investment plan.  
(v)  Prepare contract packages and draft bidding documents, and propose bidding 
procedures for items to be procured under international competitive bidding. The 
bidding documents and procurement procedures must be in line with ADB’s 
latest guidelines and standard bidding document. Prepare a contract package list 
and procurement schedule.  
(vi)  Design the program implementation framework and schedule and prepare a 
Gantt chart showing critical paths. 
(vii)  Assess  the  likely  technical  risks  facing  the  investment  plan  and  carry  out 
sensitivity analyses to check the viability of the investment components under 
these risks. 
(viii)  Prepare terms of reference, expertise requirements, and person-month estimates 
for  supervision  of  the  program  coordination  and  management,  and  other 
consulting services as identified in para. 5 (ii). 
 
2.  Air Quality Credit Line 
 
6.  To design an air quality credit line to channel funds to private sectors to improve air 
emissions, the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Discuss with selected companies or associations in the industry and transport 
sectors their plans and financial needs to comply with air emission standards and 
related requirements. 
(ii)  Review the status of the ADB TA on Clean Vehicle Fuel for Blue Skies and 
include the TA’s investment proposal in the Program, if necessary. 
(iii)  Identify investment items that will be needed by the private sector to reduce air 
emissions.  These  can  include  air  emission  reduction  equipment,  air  quality 
monitoring devices, motor vehicle emission inspection and maintenance system, 
natural  gas  distribution  network,  filling  stations  and  vehicles,  or  cleaner-
production and energy-efficient technology to meet emission standards. 
(iv)  Estimate short-term (3 years) financial needs of the private sector to invest in the 
items identified under para. 6 (iii) to reduce their air emissions. 
(v)  Review  information  related  to  prospective  financial  intermediaries  that  can 
channel funding for procurement of air emission reduction facilities or equipment 
to the private sector, review the available instruments with the intermediaries, 
and develop evaluation criteria that the intermediaries will need to satisfy to 
participate in the Program. 
(vi)  Prepare  draft  terms  for  channel  financing  and  discuss  these  with  potential 
intermediaries, including an apex bank and a channeling bank. Short-list qualified 
intermediaries with term sheets for their participation. 
(vii)  Conduct a consultation conference to disseminate and collect feedback on the 
investment design and the credit line. 
 
3.  Economic Analysis and Poverty Impact Assessment 
 
7.  As the Program will include policy and investment components, the consultant will 
conduct an economic analysis for  each. The analysis of all proposed investments will follow 
ADB’s Guidelines For The Economic Analysis Of Projects, Economic Analysis In 2002: A 
Retrospective,  and  Economic  Analysis  Retrospective:  2003  Update.  The  analysis  should 
include, but not be limited to the following:

14  Appendix 4   
(i)  Analyze quantitative and qualitative benefits of the Program and its components. 
(ii)  Provide a table detailing the conversion of economic cost from financial cost of 
the Program and the specific conversion factors used. 
(iii)  Incorporate  into  the  economic  analysis  an  economic  quantification  of  the 
Program’s environmental impacts following ADB’s  Environmental Assessment 
Guidelines  (2003,  or  subsequent  amendments),  and  Economic  Valuation  of 
Environmental  Impacts:  A  Workbook  (1996,  or  subsequent  amendments). 
Discuss and present the assumptions and methodology. 
(iv)  Assess  the  Program’s  pro-poor  impact  in  terms  of  ADB’s  poverty  reduction 
strategy.  Identify  the  fundamental  social  problems  and  analyze  all  feasible 
alternatives  for  addressing  them,  including  investment  and  policy-based 
alternatives. 
(v)  Review and discuss the assumptions and economic parameters used in the 
economic  analysis,  and  identify  and  explain  the  rationale  for  Government 
intervention and the rationale for foreign aid. 
(vi)  Identify  and  analyze  economic  uncertainties  that  can  affect  the  Program’s 
viability, and carry out a risk analysis using a suitable risk analysis model. 
 
8.  The economic analysis of the policy component will follow ADB’s Economic Analysis Of 
Policy-Based Operations: Key Dimensions. The analysis should include, but not be limited to 
the following: 
 
(i)  Review sector performance and the policy and institutional environment, and 
identify effects of policy on air quality. 
(ii)  Assess proposals or efforts to reform policies and institutions, the time needed 
for reform to take effect, and distribution effects on different stakeholder groups. 
(iii)  Compare the likely policy reform options to be supported under the Program from 
the point of view of time and distribution, and assess their implications for vested 
interests and reform supporters. 
(iv)  Identify measures needed to mitigate negative short-term impacts or improve 
inclusion of groups, such as the poor, and estimate the cost of these measures. 
(v)  Help  discuss  options  and  effects  with  stakeholder  groups,  and  use  the 
assessments to help the Government develop an implementable policy matrix 
and to develop an overall program poverty impact assessment. 
 
4.  Financial Analysis and Financial Management Assessment 
 
9.  To carry out the Program’s financial analysis, the consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Identify the project components necessary for financial analyses. 
(ii)  Carry out the financial analyses of the project components identified in the 
investment loan based on  The Guidelines for the Financial Governance and 
Management of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian Development Bank, 
2001. 
(iii)  Carry out the sensitivity analyses to ensure the Program’s robustness. 
(iv)  Prepare the financial selection criteria for the credit line through a financial 
intermediary. 
(v)  Finalize the project cost estimates, and prepare financial terms, e.g., grace 
period and disbursement profile, based on the project implementation schedule.  
(vi)  Prepare a financing plan comprising expected ADB financing and Government 
counterpart funding, including interest during construction, based on the project 
cost estimates.

Appendix 4  15   
10.   To carry out financial management assessment, the consultant will do the following: 
  
(i)  Assess  BAPPENAS’  and  implementing  agencies’  financial  management 
capabilities,  including  internal  control  mechanisms,  where  appropriate,  and 
recommend  institutional  strengthening  of  BAPPENAS’  and  implementing 
agencies’ financial management based on the assessment. 
(ii)  Prepare accounting and auditing reporting formats and timetables based on the 
Guidelines, and help BAPPENAS and implementing agencies design the project 
fund-flow mechanism. Assess the availability of Government counterpart funding. 
 
5.  Environmental and Social Assessment 
 
11.  To carry out the environmental and social assessment of the program, the consultant will 
do the following:  
 
(i)  Identify  the  environment  benefits  of  the  Program  based  on  Environmental 
Considerations in ADB Operations  (2003,  or  subsequent  amendments)  and 
Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003, or subsequent amendments), and 
prepare a strategic environmental assessment to examine the program impacts. 
(ii)  Prepare  an  initial  social  assessment  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines  to 
determine the potential social effects and mitigation measures. 
(iii)  Identify methods to ensure active public participation and collect and address 
public concerns over the Program during the public consultation conferences. 
 
6.  Training Workshops 
 
12.  The consultant will conduct one training workshop in phase 1, and two in phase 2. The 
training  workshop  in  phase  1  will focus on air quality management policy evaluation and 
development. The training workshops in phase 2 will focus on technical design of air pollution 
management activities, such as air quality monitoring, vehicle inspection, roadside emission 
testing and apprehension, traffic management, public health monitoring, and fuel quality and 
standards. 
 
7.  Study Tour 
 
13.  The  objectives  of  the  study  tour  are  to  learn  policy  development,  implementation 
coordination, and state-of-the-art strategy and technology of urban air pollution control. The 
consultants will discuss with the Government the details of the study tour at the inception stage 
of phase 1. 
 
8.  Deliverables 
 
14.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report at the end of the first month; (ii) brief 
monthly progress reports at the end of months when no other report is due; (iii) a first interim 
report, including the draft SAP, in the second week of the fourth month; (iv) a second interim 
report at the end of sixth month; (v) a draft final report at the end of tenth month; and (vi) a final 
report within three weeks after the final tripartite meeting. The final report should be in a 
publishable  form.  Tripartite  meetings  including  BAPPENAS,  implementing  agencies,  the 
consultants, and ADB will be held after  submission of the inception, interim, and draft final 
reports.
